headings.name: Visor & Surfaces
headings.description: tfjs-vis provides some UI helpers to make it easier to render visualizations in an unobtrusive way.

symbols.documentation:
The primary interface to the visor is the visor() function.

This returns a singleton instance of the Visor class. The
singleton object will be replaced if the visor is removed from the DOM for
some reason.

```js
// Show the visor
tfvis.visor();
```

An instance of the visor. An instance of this class is created using the
`visor()` function.

parameters.name: name
parameters.documentation: The name / label of this surface

parameters.name: tab
parameters.documentation: The name of the tab this surface should appear on

parameters.name: styles
parameters.documentation: Display Styles for the surface

methods.returnType: { container: any; label: any; drawArea: any; }

methods.documentation: Returns a boolean indicating if the visor is in 'fullscreen' mode
Returns a boolean indicating if the visor is open

Binds the ~ (tilde) key to toggle the visor.

This is called by default when the visor is initially created.
Unbinds the keyboard control to toggle the visor.
Sets the active tab for the visor.

headings.name: Models & Tensors
headings.description: This library exposes a show namespace that provides a number of higher level functions useful for rendering tfjs concepts. They lean towards being opinionated rather than flexible but are generally combinations of Renderers (see below), so one can easily roll their own.

subheadings.name: Model Inspection
subheadings.description: These functions are useful for examing models, layers and tensors

parameters.name: container
parameters.documentation:
A `{name: string, tab?: string}` object specifying which
surface to render to.

parameters.name: layer
parameters.documentation: a `tf.layers.Layer`

parameters.name: container
parameters.documentation:
A `{name: string, tab?: string}` object specifying which
surface to render to.

parameters.name: container
parameters.documentation:
A `{name: string, tab?: string}` object specifying which
surface to render to.

parameters.name: tensor
parameters.documentation: the input tensor

subheadings.name: Model Training
subheadings.description: These functions are useful for monitoring training.

parameters.name: container
parameters.documentation:
A `{name: string, tab?: string}` object specifying which
surface to render to.

parameters.name: metrics
parameters.documentation: List of metrics to plot.

parameters.name: opts
parameters.documentation:
Optional parameters for the line charts. See the opts parameter
for render.linechart for details. Notably for 'accuracy' related plots
the domain of the yAxis will always by 0-1, i.e. zoomToFit and yAxisDomain
options are ignored.

parameters.name: container
parameters.documentation:
A `{name: string, tab?: string}` object specifying which
surface to render to.

parameters.name: history
parameters.documentation:
A history like object. Either a tfjs-layers `History` object
or an array of tfjs-layers `Logs` objects.

parameters.name: metrics
parameters.documentation:
An array of strings for each metric to plot from the history
object. Using this allows you to control which metrics appear on the same
plot.

parameters.name: opts
parameters.documentation:
Optional parameters for the line charts. See the opts parameter
for render.linechart for details. Notably for 'accuracy' related plots
the domain of the yAxis will always by 0-1, i.e. zoomToFit and yAxisDomain
options are ignored.

subheadings.name: Model Evaluation
subheadings.description: These functions are useful for evaluating the quality of a model.

headings.name: Charts
headings.description: The library exposes a render namespace that provides a number of functions that plot particular visualizations. Most of these functions take regular JavaScript objects

parameters.name: container
parameters.documentation:
An `HTMLElement` or `Surface` in which to draw the bar
chart. Note that the chart expects to have complete control over
the contents of the container and can clear its contents at will.

parameters.name: data
parameters.documentation:
Data in the following format, (an array of objects)
[ {index: number, value: number} ... ]

parameters.name: opts
parameters.documentation: optional parameters

parameters.name: container
parameters.documentation: An `HTMLElement` or `Surface` in which to draw the chart

opts

parameters.documentation: An `HTMLElement`|`Surface` in which to draw the histogram

parameters.name: data
parameters.documentation:
Data in the following format:
`[ {value: number}, ... ]` or `[number]` or [TypedArray](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/TypedArray)

parameters.name: opts
parameters.documentation: optional parameters

parameters.name: container
parameters.documentation: An HTMLElement in which to draw the chart

parameters.name: data
opts
parameters.documentation: optional parameters

parameters.name: container
parameters.documentation: An HTMLElement in which to draw the chart

parameters.name: data
opts
parameters.documentation: optional parameters

parameters.name: container
parameters.documentation:
An `HTMLElement` or `Surface` in which to draw the table.
Note that the chart expects to have complete control over
the contents of the container and can clear its contents
at will.

parameters.name: data
parameters.documentation:
Data in the following format
{
headers: string[],
values:  any[][],
}
data.headers are the column names
data.values is an array of arrays (one for  each row). The inner
array length usually matches the length of data.headers. Usually
the values are strings or numbers, these are inserted as html
content so html strings are also supported.

headings.name: Metrics
headings.description: The metrics namespace contains a few utility functions for computing quality metrics like accuracy or creating confusion matrices.

parameters.name: labels
parameters.documentation: tensor of true values

parameters.name: predictions
parameters.documentation: tensor of predicted values

parameters.name: labels
parameters.documentation: 1D tensor of true values

parameters.name: predictions
parameters.documentation: 1D tensor of predicted values

parameters.name: numClasses
parameters.documentation:
Number of distinct classes. Optional. If not passed in
numClasses will equal the highest number in either labels or predictions
plus 1

parameters.name: weights
parameters.documentation:
1d tensor that is the same size as predictions.
If weights is passed in then each prediction contributes its corresponding
weight to the total value of the confusion matrix cell.

parameters.name: labels
parameters.documentation: 1D tensor of true values

parameters.name: predictions
parameters.documentation: 1D tensor of predicted values

parameters.name: numClasses
parameters.documentation:
Number of distinct classes. Optional. If not passed in
numClasses will equal the highest number in either labels or predictions
plus 1

symbols.documentation:
Computes per class accuracy between prediction and labels. Each value in
labels and predictions should correspond to some output class. It is assumed
that these values go from 0 to numClasses - 1.

```js
const labels = tf.tensor1d([0, 0, 1, 2, 2, 2]);
const predictions = tf.tensor1d([0, 0, 0, 2, 1, 1]);

const result = await tfvis.metrics.perClassAccuracy(labels, predictions);
console.log(JSON.stringify(result, null, 2))
```

Returns an array of objects that each have an an `accuracy` and a `count`
property for each class.
